description.narrative: Provide goods, personnel, services and assistance to meet basic human needs in order to foster transition from relief according to principles of universality, impartiality and human dignity. This element should be done, when possible, as part of an integrated, coordinated and/or multi-sectoral approach.

Supports the following illustrative program-funded costs: salaries of US, FSN, and TCN and other staff such as PSCs, RSSAs, PASAs, CASUs working for the US Government managing, administering, and supporting programs and their program-funded benefits such as housing, travel, transportation, education allowances etc; institutional contractors that provide such staff, rent, IT services, the program-funded share of utilities, staff training costs and the cost of developing and administering training programs, equipment and supplies, ICASS, vehicle fuel and maintenance, maintenance contracts, janitorial services, operational unit web page development and maintenance, outreach such as publications and the cost of their preparation (including staff costs), and technical assistance to ensure USG compliance with regulations.

description.narrative: Assist special populations which may be vulnerable or at-risk on a temporary or chronic basis whose needs are not addressed under emergency humanitarian assistance or other programs. These include groups such as the disabled; orphans, children and at-risk youth; victims of trafficking; victims of gender-based violence; refugees, returnees, ethnic minorities, internally displaced or other socially excluded groups; the elderly; and female heads of household. Depending on circumstances, services may intend to protect groups; mitigate adverse conditions they face, or to remove barriers to help integrate them into society. Components may include measures to increase the capacity of local service and advocacy NGOs and/or professional social workers; to establish public/private service delivery partnerships as well as family and community focused service models; to establish effective referral networks; to develop appropriate service protocols and methods for screening prospective recipients; or to improve public understanding and sensitivity to the needs of the vulnerable. While services provided should not exclude victims of trafficking in persons, programs designed specifically for this group fall under the Peace and Security Objective under the Transnational Crime Area and the Trafficking in Persons and Migrant Smuggling Element.

Depending on circumstances, services may intend to protect groups; mitigate adverse conditions they face, or to remove barriers to help integrate them into society. Components may include measures to increase the capacity of local service and advocacy NGOs and/or professional social workers; to establish public/private service delivery partnerships as well as family and community focused service models; to establish effective referral networks; to develop appropriate service protocols and methods for screening prospective recipients; or to improve public understanding and sensitivity to the needs of the vulnerable. While services provided should not exclude victims of trafficking in persons, programs designed specifically for this group fall under the Peace and Security Objective under the Transnational Crime Area and the Trafficking in Persons and Migrant Smuggling Element.

title.narrative: The Lao PDR Competitiveness and Trade Multi-Donor Trust Fund (LCT) with the World Bank

description.narrative: The objectives of the Competitiveness and Trade Project are to simplify business regulations, facilitate trade, and improve firm-level competitiveness. There are four components to the project, the first component being improving the business environment. The pillar aims to improve the transparency and efficiency of the general business environment to reduce the costs it currently imposes on all enterprises, and SMEs that find it more difficult to deal with complex and nontransparent procedures that are applied based on deals, rather than rules. As a result, regulatory reforms are expected to particularly benefit such companies. Throughout this pillar, emphasis will be on ensuring that reforms and initiatives benefit particularly SMEs and proportionally benefit women-led enterprises. The second component is the facilitating trade and connecting to markets. This component is designed to support the Government of Lao PDR in implementing the provisions of the WTO TFA.20 Full and effective implementation of the TFA commitments is expected to reduce the high trade costs and delays resulting from administrative procedures to obtain trade documents and clearance for imports and exports, to increase certainty and reliability of imports and exports, and to increase trade transparency. The third component is the improving firm-level competitiveness will be implemented through component C.1 (Business Assistance Facility). This component is to complement improvements in the overall business and trade environment, this pillar will support individual private enterprises in accessing business development services through a matching grant facility. The intervention aims to reduce costs internal to firms by improving company management and innovation in terms of products, markets, and distribution channels such as e-commerce.

Increase availability and use of proven nutrition interventions to reduce mortality, morbidity, and food insecurity, including nutrition education to improve maternal diets, nutrition during pregnancy, exclusive breastfeeding, and infant and young child feeding practices; fortified or biofortified staple foods, specialized food products, and community gardens to improve consumption of quality food; and delivery of nutrition services including micronutrient supplementation and community management of acute malnutrition. Strengthen host country capacity by advancing supportive nutrition and food security policies and improving nutrition information systems.

The USAID-UNICEF Partnership will expand access to quality early childhood education and smooth transition to and completion of primary schooling for children in remote areas. Parents will also be engaged so they are equipped with the knowledge and skills to support their childrens development.

Develop and conduct needs assessments, baseline studies, targeted evaluations, special studies or other information-gathering efforts specifically for the design, monitoring and evaluation of USG-funded programs. This sub-element may also include developing and disseminating best practices and lessons learned, testing demonstration and/or pilot models, or the preparation of strategic plans and other short-term programming tasks. Note: All such activities that are carried out by partners as an integral part of their monitoring and evaluation efforts for programs funded under other sub-elements should be included within those sub-elements.
Evaluation

Advance protection of international human rights, including labor rights, not covered under other elements. This element supports governmental and nongovernmental organizations created to protect, promote, and enforce human rights. Support programs to educate governments on incorporating human rights standards and practices into all government activity.

title.narrative: Improving Maternal and Child Health Outcomes

description.narrative: (Laos): .The Laos Maternal Child health and Nutrition (LMCHN) activity will address inequitable health and nutrition outcomes of the most underserved segments of the population through a targeted health system strengthening approach. It will demonstrate innovative models, building on lessons learned from previous USG and other international development partners' investments to improve health and nutrition outcomes. LMCHN will strengthen equitable access to quality health and nutrition services for adolescents, specifically the most vulnerable girls (10 to 19 years old) to ensure young pregnant women can access quality services...LMCHN will support the Government of Laos to have greater ability to steward, design, manage, and monitor a system of high-quality, integrated multi-sectoral approach reproductive, maternal, newborn, child, and adolescent health and nutrition services. Communities will strengthen their roles as active agents of change in service quality, and access to, and use of services, and the adoption of behaviors to improve health outcomes. LMCHN's goal is to improve health and nutrition outcomes among pregnant and postpartum women, newborns, children, and adolescents. LMCHN contributes to the Mission's Health Strategy 2019-2023 Intermediate Results 2.1, 2.2, and 2.4, in support of its "Laos has improved health and education systems that foster a healthier and more productive population" Development Objective. ..USAID/Laos has identified this activity for an external impact evaluation, in accordance with the USAID Evaluation Policy. This evaluation will allow USAID to rigorously test the effectiveness of LMCHN, the findings of which will greatly inform future USAID, other donor, and Government of Laos health efforts..This IM has previously received Nutrition funds; however, the current substantial pipeline means Laos will not use FY 2022 Nutrition funds for this IM....

(Laos): The USAID Legal Aid Support activity helps Laos promote the rule of law through a more consistent, fair and transparent delivery of justice in accordance with the law and promote- inclusivity of women, the poor, and traditionally underserved populations. The activity works with the Government of Laos (GOL) to improve the country's legal aid system by training legal providers at the central and provincial levels, and enhancing legal awareness and access to legal aid services. The activity also assists with budget advocacy for the government's legal aid fund to ensure that such services are sustained long-term. Legal Aid Support works to reduce the vulnerability to human trafficking among targeted populations in Laos. Training, technical assistance, and professional development of lawyers, judges, and the Ministry of Justice's legal aid officers (at the provincial and district level) better protects the rights of trafficking in persons (TIP) victims or individuals vulnerable to TIP, particularly women and girls. Village mediators learn to improve their skills in victim-centers and trauma-informed services. By supporting the GOL's efforts for Laos to become a "rule of law country", and by improving citizens' understanding of their rights and obligations under the law, USAID Legal Aid Support contributes to implementation of the Indo-Pacific Strategy. The activity also aligns with the United State Government (USG) Strategy on Women, Peace, and Security by seeking to increase participation of women in preventing, mediating, and resolving conflicts. It is essential to expand the geographical scope and duration of the activity to help Laos move toward a stronger application of the rule of law.. .

Objectives for Laos: The USAID Legal Aid Support activity aims to: 1) Strengthens the Ministry of Justice, Lao Bar Association and Non-Profit Associations; 2) Increases access to legal aid services; 3) Increases sensitivity to womens rights and empowerment in law-related professions.

description.narrative: (Laos): Learn to Read is a five-year activity that improves classroom instruction by providing teaching and learning materials; enhancing teacher competencies through training and classroom support; and strengthening community engagement in helping children learn to read. These activities aim to improve the quality of basic education in Laos, with a special focus on children who do not speak Lao at home, and children with disabilities. This activity supports the development of literacy for children from pre-primary to second grade by strengthening the literacy environment in school and at home through targeted engagement of community members. In addition to teacher training, interventions include face-to-face home visits by literacy volunteers and Village Education Development Committees, reading festivals, and family literacy days at schools. USAID and its implementing partners Save the Children, Room to Read, and Humanity & Inclusion, work with the Ministry of Education and Sports, the Ministry of Information, Culture and Tourism, and other development partners to determine effective strategies that enhance commitment to literacy and strengthen the school, home and community literacy environment.A stronger basic education system will advance Laos' national development objectives and USG goals in the basic education sector. In the long term, improved education outcomes will create more opportunities for Lao children and youth as they move toward adulthood, giving Laos' overwhelmingly young population the tools they need to help their country achieve greater economic independence. Learn to Read will also help Laos recover from the negative impacts of COVID-19 on the educational system: school closures, budget cuts, and challenges related to adapting to online learning methods.

Objectives for Laos: The USAID Learn to Read activity aims to: 1) Improves the Lao reading ability of students in pre-primary and early primary education; 2) Improves classroom instruction; 3) Enhances teacher competencies in applying effective classroom teaching and learning activities and their access to resources to meet the needs of targeted children; 4) Strengthens community engagement and the development of conducive learning environments for improved reading skills, particularly for children who do not speak Lao and children with disabilities.

(Laos): Laos Microenterprise strengthens the competitiveness of agricultural microenterprises in Laos, which remain uncompetitive and poorly integrated into domestic and regional markets. With two-thirds of the labor force working in the agriculture sector, strengthening agricultural microenterprises and improving market access will contribute to Laos' Journey to Self-Reliance as private sector investment and trade bolster this agrarian country's capacity to manage and fund its own development solutions. At the same time, agribusiness and agricultural value chain investments create opportunities for U.S. businesses seeking to diversify their overseas production base -- creating a potentially cost-effective entry point into the rapidly growing ASEAN economic community.The activity works with public and private sector partners to equip agricultural microenterprises and farmers with the skills needed to respond to market needs and access technology and facilities, while also assisting them to reduce operations costs by enhancing their negotiating power and establishing reliable linkages between microenterprise groups and markets. Laos Microenterprise also helps microenterprises gain access to finance by increasing the ability of financial institutions, such as savings banks and credit unions, to manage and assess loans as well as develop new financial products tailored to the needs of microenterprises. This is combined with support for expanding markets and establishing linkages with larger buyers both domestically and abroad.

Objectives for Laos: The project aims to: At least 8,000 supported microenterprises improve their business performance; 25 percent increase in income for beneficiary firms; 2,000 microenterprises linked to other businesses through partnerships; 180 market linkages created between farmers groups and buyers.

description.narrative: Increase availability and use of proven nutrition interventions to reduce mortality, morbidity, and food insecurity, including nutrition education to improve maternal diets, nutrition during pregnancy, exclusive breastfeeding, and infant and young child feeding practices; fortified or biofortified staple foods, specialized food products, and community gardens to improve consumption of quality food; and delivery of nutrition services including micronutrient supplementation and community management of acute malnutrition. Strengthen host country capacity by advancing supportive nutrition and food security policies and improving nutrition information systems.

Objectives for Laos: USAID works to strengthen and improve NINs foundational documents and materials, particularly the Institutes terms of reference, which includes the scope, organizational chart, budget and position descriptions required to complete the formal establishment of the Institute and enable it to undertake its mission. Objectives include: Terms of reference finalized, including organizational structure, financial and procurement policies, human resources structure including job descriptions for all required positions; Exchange visits to Vietnams Nutrition Center of Excellence with the Ministry of Health and Ministry of Home Affairs, with other regional exchanges as needed; Five-year strategic plan adopted, including a Capacity Development Plan.

title.narrative: USAID Local Solutions Support in Lao PDR

description.narrative: (Laos): The USAID Local Solutions Support Task Order aims to promote local institutions and other groups to build the capacity of local organizations to take greater ownership in shaping and addressing the development agenda for Lao People's Democratic Republic. USAID believes locally identified solutions will better address the country context and issues. Therefore, by supporting capacity development of local organizations, the program also seeks to increase the impact of U.S. foreign assistance by developing a greater understanding of capacity gaps and strengthening the ability of local organizations to effectively operationalize and manage their organizations and eventually be able to contribute to their national development, including the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).

Objectives for Laos: The USAID Local Solutions Support activity aims to: 1) Improves human resources, systems and the sustainability of local institutions; 2) Enhances the ability of local institutions to generate and diversify revenue streams; 3) Increases collaboration and connectivity among civil society institutions in Laos, within and across sectors; 4) Increases pool of local service providers capable of supporting their peers in the long term

description.narrative: (Laos): The Laos Business Environment activity is USAID's flagship economic growth activity in Laos, advancing America's Indo-Pacific vision by supporting trade between the U.S. and Laos. It lends American expertise and assistance to the Lao government's efforts to improve private sector competitiveness and open the Lao business market for investment and exports. The activity works with the Ministry of Industry and Commerce and other government agencies, Lao national and provincial chamber of commerce and industries, private businesses, and associations to enhance trade capacities and services that improve Laos' business environment. The activity focuses on improving competitiveness of small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) through technical assistance and capacity building aimed at increasing firms' entrepreneurial skills and practices, as well as their ability to expand and access markets (including the digital economy). The activity will also enhance economic governance by helping SMEs participate more effectively in public-private dialogue, building their ability to advocate for improved and predictable laws, regulations, procedures, and services that open new market opportunities. LBE also improves the ability of officials and firms to implement trade policies, regulations and procedures, empowering the private sector to more effectively drive Laos' economic development and facilitate good governance. To support this goal, in FY 2021 the activity will help address legal gaps that prevent full implementation of commercial and trade reforms instituted as part of Laos' World Trade Organization membership and its other trade commitments. The activity will support two sectors most negatively impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic. All of these actions are crucial to help Laos recover from the huge and ongoing economic impacts of COVID-19 on trade and investment particularly on SMEs.

title.narrative: Sustainable Rehabilitation Services in Lao PDR

description.narrative: (Laos): The activity aims to increase the inclusion and engagement of People with Disabilities (PWDs) in society through receipt of quality prosthetics and orthotics services and physical and occupational therapies. The primary beneficiaries of the activity are disabled Lao citizens. Working through a local non-governmental organization, the primary objectives are to: 1) strengthen human, organizational, and system capacity of the Centre for Medical Rehabilitation in the provision of prosthetics and orthotics services and physical and occupational therapies; 2) increase quality of prosthetics and orthotics services of five rehabilitation centers delivered to PWDs to optimize their abilities to function and participate as meaningful and productive members of society; and 3) facilitate referrals between networks of clinical services to enable PWDs to access the services.

Objectives for Laos: The project aims to support women, men, girls and boys with physical disabilities in Laos to gain free access to prosthetic, orthotics and physical therapy, provide training activities to develop quality standards of care while improving the quality of prostheses and increasing patient satisfaction, and strengthen clinical skills which helps provide essential rehabilitation services throughout the country.

title.narrative: USAID Nurture: Improving Community Sanitation and Nutritional Status in Key Vulnerable Areas in Laos

description.narrative: (Laos): .USAID Nurture aims to contribute to a reduction in the stunting rate of young children in targeted areas of Laos by improving infant and young child feeding (IYCF) and water, sanitation, and hygiene (WASH) practices in "1,000 days" households (homes with pregnant women and children under two years of age) and the use of quality nutrition and WASH services/facilities. .. .USAID Nurture utilizes interpersonal communication through household-level support and peer groups, and links women and children with health services. USAID Nurture also utilizes a modified community-led total sanitation approach integrating nutrition and community mobilization in order to build the capacity of communities to appraise and analyze their own nutrition, water, sanitation and hygiene environment. USAID Nurture leverages private sector relationships to facilitate supplies of products that support the uptake of targeted WASH practices. Working with nongovernmental organizations, activities will improve community use of nutrition and WASH services and facilities to improve equitable service delivery coverage. By developing a model of integrated delivery, these activities will help ensure sustainability after the life of the project, which is crucial to the USG Mission Objective of improving sustainable health for poor ethnic communities living in remote areas of Lao PDR. A healthy and educated population is a key part of enhancing the economic productivity of Lao PDR and raising the country's long-term competitiveness in the global economy, which opens new opportunities for U.S. businesses. . .

Objectives for Laos: The USAID Nurture activity aims to promote good nutrition for pregnant and lactating women and improve infant and young child feeding practices and support the Lao government as it clarifies roles and responsibilities across national, provincial and district levels to help ensure consistency and ownership of multi-sectoral nutrition efforts, and mobilize communities to conduct their own appraisal and analysis of their sanitation environment

Assist special populations which may be vulnerable or at-risk on a temporary or chronic basis whose needs are not addressed under emergency humanitarian assistance or other programs. These include groups such as the disabled; orphans, children and at-risk youth; victims of trafficking; victims of gender-based violence; refugees, returnees, ethnic minorities, internally displaced or other socially excluded groups; the elderly; and female heads of household. Depending on circumstances, services may intend to protect groups; mitigate adverse conditions they face, or to remove barriers to help integrate them into society. Components may include measures to increase the capacity of local service and advocacy NGOs and/or professional social workers; to establish public/private service delivery partnerships as well as family and community focused service models; to establish effective referral networks; to develop appropriate service protocols and methods for screening prospective recipients; or to improve public understanding and sensitivity to the needs of the vulnerable. While services provided should not exclude victims of trafficking in persons, programs designed specifically for this group fall under the Peace and Security Objective under the Transnational Crime Area and the Trafficking in Persons and Migrant Smuggling Element.

Objectives for Laos: USAID Okard aims to promote greater economic self-sufficiency, improve functional ability and well-being of persons with disabilities and their households, especially those who have mobility limitations and creating a conducive environment that allows persons with disabilities to participate optimally to the society. Objectives include: 1) Persons with disabilities and their households will have improved access to health and rehabilitation services. 2) More people with disabilities and their households will be employed or self-employed. 3) Health and economic empowerment improvements will be sustained through stakeholder engagement.

description.narrative: Under this project, Nathan Associates supported the Government of Lao PDR in making the reforms necessary for the country to join the WTO, implement the U.S.-Lao PDR Bilateral Trade Agreement (BTA), meet its obligations under the ASEAN Economic Community (AEC), and follow its strategy for economic growth and poverty reduction. We provided technical assistance to the Ministry of Industry and Commerce, other ministries, the National Assembly, the judiciary, and the Lao National Chamber of Commerce to modernize and deepen commercial laws and policies, judicial procedures, and institutional capacities in keeping with domestic needs and international best practice. In supporting the implementation of far-reaching trade agreements, the project helped advance the rule of law, improve governance, and stimulate economic growth.

person-name.narrative: Zach Child, Regional Desk Officer, East Asia

title.narrative: Trade Development Fund (a Lao multi-donor trust fund)

description.narrative: (Laos): .The Second Trade Development Trust Fund (TDF II) is a $14 million, five-year project administered by the World Bank. It is financed through a multi-donor partnership including Australia, the EU, GIZ, and Irish Aid. The TDF II supports the implementation of the government's trade and integration priorities outlined in the 2012 Diagnostic Trade Integration Study Roadmap and, in particular, to contribute to improved competitiveness, with a focus outside of the natural resource or extractive sectors. A key priority for the TDF II is to shift from a pre- to post-WTO accession agenda, with an increased focus on implementing policy reforms and following through on trade commitments to directly benefit the private sector.This contribution will support activities that decrease the regulatory burdens of cross-border trade. This complements LUNA II activities which are more focused on improving economy-wide regulatory and policy issues......
Support of Procurement and Distribution of Nutrition Commodities

person-name.narrative: Zach Child, Regional Desk Officer, East Asia

description.narrative: (Laos): The U.S. supports partnership building for economic development in Laos by utilizing Emerging Markets Development Advisers Program under Volunteers for Economic Growth Alliance (VEGA), a USAID-funded Leader with Associate (LWA) mechanism. Use of this mechanism will leverage the expertise of a USG expert to strengthen and professionalize the American Chamber of Commerce in Laos. This mechanism is a cost-effective way to bring an expert to Laos for up to two years to work with the AMCHAM Chapter, the GOL and Lao National Chamber of Commerce and Industry, other Foreign Chambers of Commerce, and other local NGOs to promote private sector development and public-private partnerships. The capacities of business organizations working in Laos are low due to lack of staff and resources, and a skilled volunteer placement in the country is a way to help bolster their activities and pave the way for future initiatives.

person-name.narrative: Zach Child, Regional Desk Officer, East Asia

description.narrative: (Laos): .Laos is a source - and to a lesser extent, a transit and destination country - for women, children and men subjected to sex trafficking and forced labor. Victims are often migrants seeking opportunities abroad, who then experience labor or sexual exploitation in destination countries, including Thailand, China, Vietnam, and others..USAID Laos Counter Trafficking In Persons (CTIP) activity works to reduce vulnerability to human trafficking among targeted populations in Laos, including women, children, and migrant workers, some of whom return during the COVID-19 pandemic. This is done through identifying their needs, supporting vocational training and employment opportunities, and increasing accessibility. Laos CTIP improves coordination among TIP agencies, especially in prevention and awareness raising activities. The activity also improves the quality of victim protection services for vulnerable people and trafficking survivors who are at risk for re-trafficking. This includes a focus on the potential for increased trafficking risks due to the harmful social and economic impacts of COVID-19. Laos CTIP showcases a model of prevention and protection for the Lao government and other partners, including civil society organizations and the private sector, from which they can better learn about and support efforts to combat human trafficking. This approach enhances coordination and concerted efforts among front line advocates and service providers, as well as anti-trafficking stakeholders at national and local levels, building their capacity and commitment to manage CTIP interventions on their own in the future. It also supports the United States' Indo-Pacific vision for advancing by centering on victims and at-risk populations, reflecting a human rights based approach.

description.narrative: Develop and conduct needs assessments, baseline studies, targeted evaluations, special studies or other information-gathering efforts specifically for the design, monitoring and evaluation of USG-funded programs. This sub-element may also include developing and disseminating best practices and lessons learned, testing demonstration and/or pilot models, or the preparation of strategic plans and other short-term programming tasks. Note: All such activities that are carried out by partners as an integral part of their monitoring and evaluation efforts for programs funded under other sub-elements should be included within those sub-elements.

Assist special populations which may be vulnerable or at-risk on a temporary or chronic basis whose needs are not addressed under emergency humanitarian assistance or other programs. These include groups such as the disabled; orphans, children and at-risk youth; victims of trafficking; victims of gender-based violence; refugees, returnees, ethnic minorities, internally displaced or other socially excluded groups; the elderly; and female heads of household. Depending on circumstances, services may intend to protect groups; mitigate adverse conditions they face, or to remove barriers to help integrate them into society. Components may include measures to increase the capacity of local service and advocacy NGOs and/or professional social workers; to establish public/private service delivery partnerships as well as family and community focused service models; to establish effective referral networks; to develop appropriate service protocols and methods for screening prospective recipients; or to improve public understanding and sensitivity to the needs of the vulnerable. While services provided should not exclude victims of trafficking in persons, programs designed specifically for this group fall under the Peace and Security Objective under the Transnational Crime Area and the Trafficking in Persons and Migrant Smuggling Element.

person-name.narrative: Zach Child, Regional Desk Officer, East Asia

title.narrative: Grant to UNICEF for Natural and Technological Risks in Laos

description.narrative: Grant to UNICEF for Natural and Technological Risks in Laos
To strengthen the capacity of the Gov. of Lao PDR officials to manage responses to humanitarian emergencies
